reviewText: I have had this movie on VHS for many years and was happy to see it released to DVD.  Megan Follows of Anne of Green Gables fame does an excellent job in this moving story of survival, love vs. hate, strength, and shattered dreams.  A pretty heavy story, this movie (I feel) is a great time piece that captures a moment in the past very well with the set, costumes, cars etc.  My favorite scene is when Megan Follows is riding the food cart at her job - a moment of true bliss for this troubled soul.  Great movie.  I can watch it again and again.
Title: N/A

reviewText: As is repeated most every review I've written, Rock and Rock DIED on Aug. 16, 1977 -yeah, Elvis took it with him.  And when the "pretenders to the throne," Disco and Punk interbred about 1980 and created the loathesome "new wave," even though I was an actively performing Rock and Roller - I quit.  Tried country and till about 1988, it had "wave" beat to mortal #%%$.  And from the rediculous to the sublime, I had alawys dug Opera, because my Mama was an avid Classical Musician herself.  So you can imagine my surprise when - on the very Saturday it was announced that our Men in Iran had been kidnapped - I watched the opera, "Rise And Fall of The City Of Mahagonny."  In all honesty though, that was not my original intent: I had gone to my friend's apartment to...um...discuss certain subjects that, say, Bob Marley and Peter Tosh espoused.  My buddy and I "got right," and then he bade me, "Hey, dig this opera on PBS."  I did, "Mahagonny," and despite the existential/socialist overtones of the "plot," the music blew me away.  I recognized the ingenue, Teresa Stratas as a woman who'd first captivated me about 1966.  But straying a bit there...Under The Piano is NOT a "party movie," it's something one should remove distractions and devote full attention to.  Phenominal cast, Amanda Plummer plays Fanny, a "don't argue with me"/older sister-protecter to Megan Follows' Rosetta.  And Ms. Stratas, in a totally non-singing role, plays their Mom, a retired, kind of "forgotten but not...quite...gone" opera singer (kind of like "Journey" or "Foreigner" is to rock and roll.)  The plot - and remember, this was originally a Canadian TV special - is like 99.9% of all English movies (hey...even though it's socialist, Canada IS still an English province), just STONE BORING.  Something about the older sister guarding the younger sister.  It gets weird, the younger sister has, as the liner notes say, "an exceptional musical talent."  Yeah -  the daughter who is autistic.  Still: despite the utterly confusing "plot," Ms. Plummer and Ms. Follows are both enchanting, but - you've been waiting for me to say it - I could/can not take my eyes off Ms. Stratas, a woman who is as captivating in a relatively minor role as she was performing in any number of opera ("opera," BTW is the plural of the noun "opus"...for you Trivial Persuit fans)  I dig opera, as I've said, but Ms. Stratas - I do sincerely wish that she was the Jane Seymour and I was the Christopher Reeve in "Somewhere In Time."

reviewText: A very good movie and introduction to autism.  It showed the loyalty necessary when a family member is afficted by a condition that never goes away.  Autism cant be cured but can be managed sucessfully by people that know how.  In this movie the surrounding family did not aways know how but always loved and were so loyal.  Very moving movie about ordinary lives.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Any opera person will buy this neglected film for Teresa Stratas in a speaking role, and she does not disappoint.  Where Stratas had a huge career, her character in the film is a never-was prima donna turned captious voice teacher and utterly failed mother whose rigidity drives one child away and another--a deeply autistic daughter--to attempt suicide.  It is not a fun topic and it is not a fun movie, but a sad portrait of a family that cannot quite assemble itself to support its weakest OR its strongest links.  Amanda Plummer is quite fine as the elder daughter, and Megan Follows is scarily real as the autistic girl.  Hard to say "wonderful" about a film as sad as this, but there it is.

reviewText: This movie is hard to watch at times because Meghan Follows is autistic and she does some horrible stuff to herself.  Plus her mother treats her badly.  I did like how her sister had such a close connection with her.
summary: Under the Piano could be called instead:  Hit your head on the wall.
